questions.prompt: In BG 1.1, what does Dhritarastra ask Sanjaya to describe?
choices: What his sons and the Pandavas did after assembling on the battlefield
Why Krsna came to the battlefield
questions.feedback: Dhritarastra asks about what his sons and the Pandavas are doing after assembling for battle.

questions.prompt: Why does Duryodhana go to meet his teacher Drona in BG 1.2?
choices: To boast confidently about his strong army
To ask for his blessing before the war
To secretly express his worries about the battle
To secretly test Drona's loyalty to the Kurus
questions.feedback: Although Duryodhana tries to sound confident, his words actually show that he is worried about the upcoming war.

questions.prompt: How do the Pandavas respond when Bhisma blows his conchshell in BG 1.13?
choices: They blow their own conchshells in response
questions.feedback: The Pandavas respond to Bhisma by blowing many conchshells, showing they are ready and united.

questions.prompt: What does Arjuna ask Krsna to do in BG 1.21-1.22?
choices: Negotiate peace with the opposing side
Place the chariot between the armies so he can see who is there
Drive him away from the battlefield
questions.feedback: Arjuna asks Krsna to position the chariot so he can see all the warriors assembled for battle.

questions.prompt: What happens to Arjuna after he sees his relatives on the battlefield in BG 1.26?
questions.feedback: When Arjuna sees his grandfathers, teachers, and cousins, he feels compassion and sadness rather than readiness to fight.

questions.prompt: In BG 1.29-1.30, what physical symptoms does Arjuna describe?
choices: His body trembles, his vision becomes unclear, and he cannot stand steady
questions.feedback: Arjuna describes his body trembling, his mind becoming confused, and his vision becoming cloudy due to his emotional distress.

questions.prompt: What does Arjuna say about fighting his own relatives in BG 1.31?
choices: He sees no good in killing his own family members
questions.feedback: Arjuna believes there is no good outcome from fighting people who are his own blood relatives.

questions.prompt: What does Arjuna question the value of in BG 1.32-1.35?
choices: A kingdom and happiness if they come from killing relatives
questions.feedback: Arjuna argues that neither a kingdom nor happiness would be worth anything if obtained by killing his own family.

questions.prompt: In BG 1.36, what does Arjuna fear will happen if he fights?
questions.feedback: Arjuna believes that by killing his own relatives, he will do something wrong and become tainted with sin.

questions.prompt: What does Arjuna say happens to a family when its traditions are destroyed in BG 1.39-1.40?
choices: Bad practices spread and the family's way of life is corrupted
questions.feedback: Arjuna warns that destroying family traditions leads to problems, dishonesty, and the breakdown of good family values.

questions.prompt: According to Arjuna in BG 1.41, what happens to the ancestors of families that lose their traditions?
choices: They are happy with the changes
They lose the honor of receiving respect and proper ceremonies
They become kings of other lands
questions.feedback: When families stop performing proper ceremonies and respecting tradition, the ancestors no longer receive honor and remembrance.

questions.prompt: In BG 1.43, what has Arjuna heard about families that destroy their traditions?
choices: They suffer bad consequences for their actions
They become famous throughout the world
questions.feedback: Arjuna has been taught that families who destroy their traditions face serious consequences for harming their own people.

questions.prompt: In BG 1.44, what does Arjuna think is strange about the situation?
choices: Everyone is well trained and skilled
People are ready to do something harmful just to gain power and wealth
questions.feedback: Arjuna is shocked that people's desire for power and possessions makes them willing to harm even their own family.

questions.prompt: What does Arjuna say would be better for him personally in BG 1.45?
choices: To win the war and rule the kingdom
To be killed by his enemies while not fighting back
To run away and never return
To hide until the war ends
questions.feedback: Arjuna expresses that it would be better to die unarmed and defenseless than to kill his own relatives.

questions.prompt: What is Arjuna's condition at the end of Chapter 1 in BG 1.46?
choices: He stands ready to fight with confidence
He puts down his weapons and sits down, overcome with sadness and confusion
questions.feedback: At the end of Chapter 1, Arjuna is so confused and sad that he puts down his bow and arrows and sits in the chariot overwhelmed by grief.
